title: Lab 27 – Memo Peer Review Framework
text: Establish a structured rubric for peer feedback on policy memos.

title: Lab 27 – Memo Peer Review Framework
text: Establish a structured rubric for peer feedback on policy memos.

title: Lab 27 – Memo Peer Review Framework
text:
Review Criteria

Clarity of Executive Summary
Historical relevance and accuracy
Use of data and visualizations
Strength of recommendations
Writing style and formatting

title: Lab 27 – Memo Peer Review Framework
text:
Prompt
Exchange memos with a peer and provide constructive feedback using the rubric above. Reflect on how the review process improved your own memo.

title: Lab 25 – Policy Memo Template
text: Provide a reusable memo framework for students to present historical analysis as policy advice.

title: Lab 25 – Policy Memo Template
text: Provide a reusable memo framework for students to present historical analysis as policy advice.

title: Lab 25 – Policy Memo Template
text:
Template Sections

To: [Decision-maker]
From: [Your Name]
Date: [Insert Date]
Subject: [Concise Topic]
Executive Summary: [Key findings and recommendations]
Background: [Historical context and relevance]
Analysis: [Data-driven insights]
Recommendations: [Actionable steps]
Appendix: [Visuals, tables, citations]

title: Lab 25 – Policy Memo Template
text:

title: Lab 17 – Clustering States by Historical Indicators
text: Group countries based on historical indicators using k-means clustering.

title: Lab 17 – Clustering States by Historical Indicators
text: Group countries based on historical indicators using k-means clustering.

title: Lab 17 – Clustering States by Historical Indicators
text:
Prompt:
What patterns emerge in the clusters? Are there geographic or ideological groupings?

title: Lab 17 – Clustering States by Historical Indicators
text:
Load Data
```{webr-r. lab06b} library(tidyverse)
indicators <- read_csv(here::here(“assets/datasets/state_indicators.csv”)) set.seed(42) clusters <- kmeans(indicators[, -1], centers = 4) indicators\(cluster <- clusters\)cluster
ggplot(indicators, aes(x = literacy_rate, y = military_spending, color = factor(cluster))) + geom_point() + labs(title = “Clustering States by Historical Indicators”, x = “Literacy Rate”, y = “Military Spending”) + theme_minimal() ```

title: Policy Memo: Strategic Response to Rebellion Risk
text:
Strategic Response to Rebellion Risk


Prepared for: Ministry of Foreign Affairs

title: Policy Memo: Strategic Response to Rebellion Risk
text:
Executive Summary
Recent simulations indicate a heightened risk of rebellion in regions with low GDP per capita and high ethnic fractionalization. This memo outlines strategic policy responses based on quantitative modeling.

title: Policy Memo: Strategic Response to Rebellion Risk
text:
Simulation Findings
source(“assets/scripts/simulate_rebellion.R”) simulate_rebellion(gdp = 950, regime = “autocracy”, ethnic_frac = 0.72, repression = 0.85)

title: Lab 04 – Tracing the Spread of Revolution
text: Track revolutionary activity from 1789 to 1900 and explore spatial diffusion patterns.

title: Lab 04 – Tracing the Spread of Revolution
text:

What patterns emerge? Do revolutionary waves cluster in specific regions or periods? Identify possible causes.

title: Lab 04 – Tracing the Spread of Revolution
text:
Data
library(tidyverse)

revolutions <- read_csv(here::here("assets/datasets/revolution_events.csv"))

revolutions %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, fill = country)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5) +
  labs(title = "Frequency of Revolutionary Events",
       x = "Year", y = "Number of Events") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Lab 03 – Colonial Administration Models
text:
Data Load
library(tidyverse)

admin <- read_csv(here::here("assets/datasets/colonial_budgets.csv"))

admin %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = region, y = budget, fill = expense_type)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack") +
  labs(title = "Colonial Budget Allocations by Region",
       y = "Budget (in millions)", x = "Region") +
  theme_minimal()

pop_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = population, color = empire)) +
  geom_line(size=1) +
  labs(title = "Colonial Population Growth (1800–1900)",

  theme_minimal()

title: Lab 02 – Mapping Empire Trade
text:
Setup
library(tidyverse)

trade <- read_csv(here::here("assets/datasets/imperial_trade.csv"))

trade %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = export_value, y = commodity, fill = empire)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  labs(title = "Colonial Commodity Exports by Empire",
       x = "Export Value (in millions)", y = "Commodity") +
  theme_bw()

title: Welcome to IS655: International History
text: Welcome to IS655, a graduate seminar at Old Dominion University taught by Dr. Austin Jersild. This site hosts 100 interactive labs exploring international history through data visualization, policy modeling, and computational analysis using R and Quarto.

title: Welcome to IS655: International History
text: Welcome to IS655, a graduate seminar at Old Dominion University taught by Dr. Austin Jersild. This site hosts 100 interactive labs exploring international history through data visualization, policy modeling, and computational analysis using R and Quarto.

title: IS655: International History Labs
text:
Summary of Git Branching Commands

Create and switch to a new branch: git checkout -b new-feature-name
Work on the branch: (Make your code changes) git add . git commit -m "Describe your work"
Switch back to the main branch: git checkout main
Update your local main branch (important!): git pull origin main
Merge your new feature into main: git merge new-feature-name
Push the updated main branch to GitHub: git push origin main
Delete your local feature branch (optional cleanup): git branch -d new-feature-name




Where Do These Commands Run?
This is a breakdown of where each type of command operates:

Workspace (Working Directory):

What it is: The actual files and folders you can see and edit on your computer.
Think of it as: Your workbench.

Local Repository (Local Repo):

What it is: The hidden .git directory inside your project. It’s Git’s private database on your machine, storing all history, branches, and commits.
Think of it as: Your private library of snapshots.

Remote Repository (Remote Repo):

What it is: The version of your repository hosted on a server like GitHub.
Think of it as: The central, public library for collaboration and backup.





Command Breakdown








Command
Where it Acts
What it Does




git checkout -b ...
Local Repo & Workspace
Creates a new branch in your local repo and updates your workspace files to match.


git add .
Workspace -> Local Repo
Adds changes from your workspace to the staging area (in the local repo).


git commit -m "..."
Local Repo
Saves a permanent snapshot (commit) of the staged files into your local repo’s history.


git checkout main
Local Repo & Workspace
Switches the active branch in your local repo and updates your workspace files.


git merge ...
Local Repo & Workspace
Combines history from another branch into your current branch in the local repo and updates the workspace.


git branch -d ...
Local Repo
Deletes a branch from your local repo.


git pull origin main
Remote -> Local
Connects to the remote. Fetches changes from the remote repo and merges them into your local branch.


git push origin main
Local -> Remote
Connects to the remote. Sends commits from your local repo up to the remote repo.



The Big Takeaway: You work entirely locally. The only two common commands that contact the remote server are git pull and git push.

title: Lab 26 – Data-Driven Policy Memo
text:
Load Data
# library(tidyverse)

# reconstruction <- read_csv(here::here("assets/datasets/post_conflict_reconstruction.csv"))
# ggplot(reconstruction, aes(x = year, y = aid_received, color = country)) +
#   geom_line() +
